content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see four sections of tissue which, based on their round shape and basophilic appearance, are consistent with lymph nodes. All four nodes appear enlarged and almost entirely replaced by a dense, purple cellular infiltrate, suggesting they are all positive for metastatic tumor. The normal lymph node architecture appears to be effaced. My initial impression is that these are multiple tumor-positive lymph nodes from a colorectal cancer resection.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, the task is to identify and confirm positive lymph nodes. I would systematically examine each node. This is the first lymph node from the bottom-left. Even at low power, it appears suspicious for metastasis due to its size and monotonous purple appearance. I would zoom into this area to confirm the presence of malignant cells, characterize their morphology (e.g., adenocarcinoma), and assess the extent of involvement, specifically looking at the edge of the node for any potential extranodal extension (tumor breaking through the capsule into the surrounding fat). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic evaluation of each lymph node on the slide. The green box is located on the second lymph node from the left. When searching for metastasis, it is crucial to examine the entire lymph node at higher magnification, starting from the subcapsular sinus and moving inwards through the cortex and medulla. This specific zoom is to assess the cellular architecture of the lymphoid follicles and interfollicular areas to identify any non-native, atypical cells that would suggest metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task for these lymph nodes is to search for any evidence of metastasis from the colorectal cancer. I would systematically examine each of the four lymph nodes. The zoom is on the third lymph node from the left. This is a routine part of the microscopic examination to assess the cellular architecture at higher magnification, specifically looking for atypical cells, glandular structures, or nests of tumor cells that would be inconsistent with normal or reactive lymphoid tissue. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic evaluation of all lymph nodes on the slide. This is the fourth lymph node from the left. The specific area of interest, indicated by the green box, is at the periphery of the lymph node, in the subcapsular region. Metastatic tumor cells from carcinomas typically arrive via afferent lymphatic vessels and first colonize the subcapsular sinus. Therefore, this is a high-yield area that must be carefully scrutinized for early metastatic deposits. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area, which is the periphery of the first lymph node from the top, to carefully examine the lymph node capsule and the surrounding pericapsular fat. This is a critical region to check for two main reasons: 1) metastatic tumor cells often first deposit in the subcapsular sinus, located just beneath the capsule, and 2) I need to assess for extracapsular extension (extranodal extension), where the tumor breaks through the capsule and invades the adjacent fat, which is a significant adverse prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see that the normal lymphoid tissue is almost completely replaced by a malignant infiltrate. The tumor consists of sheets of atypical cells with large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. The cells are arranged in poorly formed glandular and nested structures. There are also some areas of necrosis. My impression is that this is a lymph node massively involved by metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with a primary colorectal cancer. I would classify this lymph node as positive for metastasis.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see the classic features of a reactive lymph node. There are numerous well-defined lymphoid follicles, some of which exhibit lighter-staining germinal centers, indicating a reactive process (follicular hyperplasia). The predominant cells are small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. There are no clusters of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glandular formations, or significant necrosis to suggest the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is that it is benign, reactive lymphoid tissue, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see dense lymphoid tissue composed of follicles, which are aggregates of lymphocytes. The large white space is a processing artifact (a tear in the tissue). The surrounding cellular population consists predominantly of small, dark-staining lymphocytes. I do not see any definite metastatic tumor cells, such as malignant glands or large, pleomorphic cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm. My impression of this specific field of view is that it shows reactive lymphoid tissue, and it appears negative for metastasis. However, the entire lymph node would need to be scrutinized to make a final diagnosis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the cortex of a lymph node. There are multiple lymphoid follicles, some with pale germinal centers, which is indicative of a reactive process (follicular hyperplasia). A prominent, irregularly shaped, clear space is visible, which represents a dilated subcapsular sinus. At the bottom of the image, there is perinodal adipose tissue. I do not see any definitive nests of atypical epithelial cells or glandular structures that would be characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is a reactive lymph node with sinus dilatation. There is no evidence of malignancy in this view.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the edge of a lymph node, characterized by a dense population of lymphocytes on the right. This is bordered by a fibrous capsule and surrounded by mature adipose tissue (fat) on the left. Several small blood vessels are present in the pericapsular connective tissue. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glands, or nests of tumor cells in this specific field. Therefore, my impression of this particular area is that it is negative for metastatic carcinoma and shows no evidence of extracapsular extension.
